questions.text: A 5-year-old girl was found unresponsive after playing with a doll she had washed using a pesticide-containing shampoo. The product was later identified to contain rotenone, a known mitochondrial toxin. Which component of the mitochondrial electron transport chain is specifically inhibited by this compound?
questions.solution:
Rotenone is a plant-derived insecticide that interferes with Complex I of the mitochondrial electron transport chain (ETC), also referred to as NADH dehydrogenase.

Electron Transport Chain:

  • ETC complexes are present in the inner mitochondrial membrane
  • There are 5 protein complexes in ETC: Complex I to V
  • ETC is located in the inner mitochondrial membrane
  • Comprises 5 protein complexes: Complexes I to V

questions.text: A man originally from the Mediterranean region develops malaria during a trip to sub-Saharan Africa. After being started on primaquine, he presents with fatigue, jaundice, and dark-colored urine. Laboratory tests reveal a drop in hemoglobin and signs of hemolysis. A deficiency in which metabolic pathway is most likely contributing to this reaction?
questions.solution:
The condition described is associated with a deficiency in the Hexose Monophosphate (HMP) pathway, more specifically involving the enzyme glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD).

Hexose Monophosphate Pathway (HMP):

  • The HMP pathway is vital in red blood cells (RBCs) as it generates NADPH, which is essential for maintaining glutathione in its reduced form.
  • Reduced glutathione (GSH) protects RBCs from oxidative stress, such as that caused by primaquine.
  • G6PD is the rate-limiting enzyme of the HMP pathway.
  • In G6PD deficiency, NADPH production is impaired, leading to glutathione depletion.
  • This makes RBCs vulnerable to oxidative injury, resulting in Heinz body formation, membrane damage, and hemolysis. 

Explanation of other options:

Glycolysis (Option A) pathway produces ATP from glucose, especially important in RBCs, which lack mitochondria. However, it does not produce NADPH and is not involved in counteracting oxidative agents.

Gluconeogenesis (Option B) is a liver-based pathway that synthesizes glucose from non-carbohydrate sources, especially during fasting. It does not protect RBCs from oxidative stress.

Luebering-Rapoport shunt (Option D): A bypass within glycolysis found in RBCs that controls levels of 2,3-bisphosphoglycerate (2,3-BPG), which affects hemoglobin's oxygen affinity. It plays no role in antioxidant defense or in drug-induced hemolysis.

Reference: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/30697723/

questions.text: A football player had a twist in the ankle and knee. Clinically, no bony injury was appreciated. The examiner is performing a test to assess the knee joint. Which test is this?
questions.solution:
This test evaluates the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) by assessing the stability of the knee. With the knee flexed at approximately 20-30 degrees, the examiner stabilizes the femur with one hand and pulls the tibia forward with the other. Increased forward movement of the tibia relative to the femur indicates ACL injury.

Lachman Test:

  • The patient is in the supine position.
  • Knee flexed to 30°.
  • The examiner stabilizes the distal femur with one hand and, with the other hand, pulls the tibia forward with the thumb on the tibial tuberosity.
  • The test is positive when there is increased anterior tibial translation relative to the femur.
  • Tibial translation of more than 5 mm indicated ACL rupture.
  • More reliable and more sensitive than the anterior drawer test because it is performed with the knee flexed at 30°, reducing the influence of the hamstrings, especially the biceps femoris.
  • Most sensitive for ACL injury assessment.

Posterior Drawer for PCL (Option A) assesses the integrity of the posterior cruciate ligament (PCL). The examiner applies a posterior force to the tibia while the patient is in a supine position with the knee flexed. A positive test shows excessive posterior movement of the tibia relative to the femur, indicating PCL injury.

McMurray Test (Option B) is used to assess meniscal tears. The examiner rotates the tibia while the knee is flexed and extended. Pain or a "click" during this maneuver suggests a meniscal tear, but it is not specific for ligament injuries.

Anterior Drawer for ACL (Option D) is used to assess the ACL. The patient lies supine with the knee flexed at 90 degrees. The examiner pulls the tibia forward while stabilizing the femur. Increased anterior movement of the tibia relative to the femur indicates ACL injury. Lachmann test is more sensitive.

Reference:

  1. Anterior Cruciate Ligament Knee Injury - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf (nih.gov)
  2. Lachman Test - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf (nih.gov)
  3. https://www.jospt.org/doi/pdf/10.2519/jospt.1995.22.6.263

questions.text: The following test is done to assess?
questions.solution:
Image shows Pen test, done to test Abductor pollicis brevis muscle which is a test of Median nerve.


Treatment of median nerve palsy:

  • Conservative management mainly.
  • If not recovered, nerve repair is done by
    • High median nerve palsy (above elbow): 9 months
    • Low median nerve palsy (distal forearm): 12 months

questions.text: A professional singer complains of difficulty hitting high notes. Laryngoscopy reveals bowing of the right vocal cord. Which muscle is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
• The cricothyroid muscle plays a key role in modulating vocal pitch by tightening and lengthening the vocal cords. This function allows for the production of higher-pitched sounds.
  • It is the only intrinsic laryngeal muscle innervated by the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve, a branch of the vagus nerve (cranial nerve X).
  • Injury to the cricothyroid muscle or its nerve supply can result in vocal cord slackness, limiting the ability to reach high notes, which is often first noticed by singers.
  • Additionally, this can lead to subtle voice changes such as hoarseness and vocal fatigue. The finding of vocal cord bowing suggests reduced tension and tone, consistent with impaired cricothyroid function.



Explanation of other options:

Posterior cricoarytenoid (Option A): Incorrect. This is the only muscle that abducts the vocal cords (opens the glottis). It is not involved in pitch control.

Lateral cricoarytenoid (Option B): Incorrect. This muscle adducts (closes) the vocal cords but does not contribute to pitch modulation.

Thyroarytenoid (Option D): Incorrect. This muscle relaxes the vocal cords, allowing for lower-pitched phonation.

questions.text: During a clinical examination, the clinician touches the highlighted structure to evaluate sensory function. Which cranial nerve is responsible for conveying sensation from this area?
questions.solution:
• The sensory input from the uvula and posterior pharyngeal wall is carried by the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX), which forms the afferent limb of the reflex arc involved in protecting the airway.
  • The glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) is the primary sensory nerve for the posterior part of the tongue, oropharynx, soft palate, and uvula.
  • When the uvula or surrounding area is touched, it triggers the afferent limb of the gag reflex via this nerve.
  • This nerve transmits sensation to the nucleus solitarius in the medulla, which coordinates reflex responses.
  • The gag reflex (pharyngeal reflex) depends on CN IX for sensation and CN X for motor output.
  • Damage to CN IX can lead to a loss of sensation in the oropharynx and an absent or diminished response when the uvula or posterior pharynx is stimulated.
  • Testing sensation in this area is crucial for evaluating the integrity of the brainstem and cranial nerves, particularly in conditions like brainstem stroke or brain death.

Explanation of other options:

Vagus nerve (option B): While it mediates the motor response during the gag reflex and innervates muscles of the palate and pharynx, it does not provide the sensory input from the uvula.

Accessory nerve (option C): Supplies motor function to the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles. It has no sensory or motor role in the pharynx or gag reflex.

Hypoglossal nerve (option D): Controls tongue movements. It’s not involved in gag reflex pathways or uvular sensation.

Reference:

  1. Cranial Nerves IX and X: The Glossopharyngeal and Vagus Nerves - Clinical Methods - NCBI Bookshelf
  2. Neuroanatomy, Cranial Nerve 9 (Glossopharyngeal) - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf
  3. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK554502/

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with difficulty breathing and a history of recurrent respiratory tract infections. Chest X-ray and CT imaging findings are shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of recurrent respiratory tract infections and breathing difficulty in a child, along with chest X-ray showing a cystic mass in the left lower lobe and CT chest confirming multiple cystic lesions in the same region, point towards a diagnosis of Congenital Pulmonary Airway Malformation (CPAM).

AP view of chest radiograph showing Left lower lobe CPAM


CT chest (coronal view) showing left lower lobe CPAM


Congenital Pulmonary Airway Malformation (CPAM):

  • A congenital lung condition involving abnormal dysplastic development of airway structures.
  • Etiology:
    • Results from abnormal lung development during early gestation, typically between 5-7 weeks, affecting terminal bronchioles.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Often appears in the newborn period or early infancy.
    • Common symptoms include respiratory distress, recurrent lung infections, and sometimes pneumothorax.
  • Imaging Features:
    • Chest X-ray: Shows cystic, solid, or mixed lesions, often unilateral, with potential mediastinal shift in larger lesions.
    • CT scan: Definitive, revealing the size, number, and type of cysts.
  • Management:
    • Prenatal diagnosis may allow for in-utero intervention in severe cases.
    • Asymptomatic cases may be monitored conservatively.
    • Surgical resection (lobectomy) is typically required for symptomatic, large, or complicated lesions.

Explanation of other options:

Lung abscess (Option A): Appears as a thick-walled cavity with an air-fluid level, often due to infection.

Pyopneumothorax (Option C): Characterized by air and pus in the pleural space; imaging shows an air-fluid level along with collapsed lung tissue.

Congenital diaphragmatic hernia (Option D): Shows abdominal organs (e.g., bowel loops) herniated into the chest cavity with a shift in mediastinal structures, not isolated lung cysts.

questions.text: A child presents with signs of a high-flow arteriovenous shunt and high-output cardiac failure. The following is his MRA. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The MRA image demonstrates features consistent with a Vein of Galen malformation (VGM), a rare congenital vascular anomaly that results from abnormal connections between cerebral arteries and deep midline veins, specifically the median prosencephalic vein, which is the embryologic precursor to the vein of Galen.

In this condition, arterial blood is shunted directly into the venous system without passing through capillaries, leading to a high-flow arteriovenous shunt. This can result in high-output cardiac failure, especially in neonates and infants, due to the increased preload on the heart.

Vein of Galen Malformation:


  • A rare congenital arteriovenous malformation (AVM) resulting from abnormal connections between arteries and the median prosencephalic vein, an embryonic precursor to the vein of Galen.
  • Types of VGM:
    • Choroidal type:
      • Involves multiple arterial feeders.
      • Typically causes high-output cardiac failure in neonates.
    • Mural type:
      • Fewer fistulas, often presents later with hydrocephalus or neurological symptoms.
  • Imaging Features:
    • Ultrasound (with Doppler): Midline, cystic-appearing structure with turbulent flow.
    • MRI/MRA:
      • Critical for identifying arterial feeders (e.g., posterior cerebral, choroidal arteries) and the dilated median prosencephalic vein, aiding in treatment planning.
  • Management:
    • Endovascular embolization is often performed in stages, especially in neonates, to minimize complications.
    • Medical management of heart failure (e.g., diuretics, inotropes) may be required prior to intervention.

Explanation of other options:

Dandy Walker syndrome (Option B): It may cause hydrocephalus, mimicking some neurological symptoms (e.g., increased intracranial pressure) of VGM, but lacks vascular shunting or high-output cardiac failure.

Pneumocephalus (Option C): Presence of intracranial air, usually after trauma or surgery. It appears as air densities on CT, not vascular abnormalities on MRA, and does not cause a high-output cardiac state.

Venous sinus thrombosis (Option D): Thrombosis of dural sinuses, which may cause headaches, seizures, or increased intracranial pressure. While MRA or MRV may help diagnose this, it does not present with a left-to-right shunt or heart failure.

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant presents with persistent jaundice and pale, clay-colored stools. Laboratory studies reveal elevated conjugated bilirubin. Liver biopsy shows evidence of bile duct proliferation around the portal tracts. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The infant's presentation of prolonged jaundice, clay-colored stools, and conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, along with periductal bile duct proliferation on liver biopsy, is consistent with a diagnosis of biliary atresia.

Extrahepatic Biliary Atresia (EHBA):

  • A progressive fibro-obliterative disease of the extrahepatic bile ducts, leading to bile flow obstruction and cholestasis in early infancy.
  • Onset: Symptoms typically present between 2-8 weeks of age, though delayed presentation up to 3 months can occur in some cases.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Persistent jaundice
    • Pale (acholic) stools
    • Dark urine
    • Hepatomegaly
  • Investigations:
    • Liver Function Tests:
      • Elevated conjugated bilirubin, ALP, GGT
      • Elevated GGT, often significantly raised, supports an extrahepatic cause like biliary atresia, while moderately elevated GGT may suggest intrahepatic cholestasis.
    • Ultrasound:
      • First-line imaging
      • Suggestive signs:
        • Triangular cord sign (fibrous remnant at porta)
        • Absent or small gallbladder
    • HIDA Scan (Tc-IDA):
      • Shows absent or poor excretion of tracer into the duodenum after 24 hours, highly suggestive of biliary atresia.
      • Phenobarbitone pretreatment (5 mg/kg/day for 5 days) enhances bile flow to improve test sensitivity.
    • Liver Biopsy:
      • Key diagnostic tool.
      • Shows bile duct proliferation, fibrosis, and cholestasis, and is often used to confirm biliary atresia in conjunction.
  • Management:
    • Kasai Procedure (Hepaticojejunostomy):
      • Temporary surgical bypass to drain bile
      • Ideally performed before 8 weeks of age
    • Liver transplantation:
      • Definitive treatment, especially if Kasai fails or is delayed

Explanation of other options:

Crigler-Najjar syndrome (Option A): Causes unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia due to defective bilirubin conjugation; liver biopsy is typically unremarkable.

Rotor syndrome (Option B): Mild conjugated hyperbilirubinemia with normal liver architecture on biopsy; no cholestasis or clay-colored stools.

Dubin-Johnson syndrome (Option C): Causes conjugated hyperbilirubinemia due to impaired excretion of conjugated bilirubin, leading to pigment deposition in the liver (dark pigmented liver). It is usually benign, without pale stools or bile duct proliferation.

Reference: https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/liverextrahepaticbiliaryatresia.html

questions.text:
During a routine home visit, a community health worker evaluates several infants for risk factors that may predispose them to growth faltering and illness. Which of the following children should be classified as "at-risk" and require closer follow-up?

1. Baby with a birth weight of 2.5 kg
2. Baby who is artificially fed
3. Baby with a working mother or single parent
4. Baby whose weight is less than 85% of what is expected
5. Baby with birth order three or more
questions.solution:
In this scenario, artificial feeding (Option 2) and lack of full-time caregiving due to a single working parent (Option 3) are well-established risk factors for inadequate nutrition, growth issues, and vulnerability to infections. These children are considered "at-risk" and warrant close monitoring and support by health services.

At-Risk Infants:

  • Early identification and close monitoring of infants who fall under the "at-risk" category is essential for reducing neonatal and infant mortality.
  • These infants are more prone to illness, poor growth, and developmental delays and therefore need additional care and support.
  • Criteria for Identification:
    • Low birth weight (< 2.5 kg) (Option 1)
    • Multiple gestation births (e.g., twins)
    • Higher birth order (fifth child or beyond) (Option 5)
    • Non-breastfed infants (those on artificial feeding) (Option 2)
    • Underweight status (weight <70% of expected weight) (Option 4)
    • Failure to gain adequate weight over three consecutive months
    • History of recurrent diarrhea or presence of protein-energy malnutrition (PEM)
    • Infants raised by single parents or working mothers with restricted time for infant care (Option 3)
  • These indicators help health workers and caregivers recognize infants who are at greater risk for complications.
  • Early intervention can greatly improve health outcomes in these children.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient is scheduled for elective cardiac surgery. To reduce the risk of postoperative infections, which of the following antibiotics is the drug of choice for preoperative prophylaxis?
questions.solution:
Cefazolin is a first-generation cephalosporin antibiotic commonly used for preoperative antibiotic prophylaxis in patients undergoing cardiac surgery. It works by inhibiting the growth and multiplication of bacteria that can cause surgical infections.


Penicillin G (Option A ): It isn't often used in cardiac surgery prophylaxis due to its limited spectrum of activity, which doesn't cover all potential infection-causing bacteria.

Erythromycin (Option B): It isn't commonly used in cardiac surgery prophylaxis because it's less effective than other antibiotics in preventing surgical infections.

Azithromycin (Option C): It isn't commonly used in cardiac surgery prophylaxis because it's ineffective against all bacteria that can cause surgical infections.

Reference: https://www.choc.org/userfiles/AntibioticProphylaxisForSurgeryGuideline.pdf

questions.text: What should be the next course of action in managing a 50-year-old patient who has a medical history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus, and is currently presenting with a feeble pulse and a blood pressure reading of 90/40 mm Hg?
questions.solution:
Paroxysmal Supraventricular Tachycardia (PSVT) is characterised by a rapid heart rhythm, which in this case is associated with low blood pressure and a weak pulse, making the situation haemodynamically unstable. Immediate intervention is essential for stabilisation.

DC Cardioversion: Direct current (DC) cardioversion delivers a synchronised electrical shock, which is the most effective and rapid method to terminate the tachycardia. This restores sinus rhythm, improving cardiac output and blood pressure in unstable patients.

IV adenosine (Option A): Adenosine can transiently halt the tachycardia by inducing temporary AV nodal block. However, in haemodynamically unstable patients, it is not the first choice as it may worsen the instability by causing transient asystole or severe bradycardia.

IV Diltiazem (Option B): Diltiazem slows AV nodal conduction and can terminate PSVT. However, in patients with low blood pressure and haemodynamic instability, it is contraindicated as it may further depress cardiac output and exacerbate hypotension.

Ibutilide (Option D): Ibutilide, a class III antiarrhythmic, has a slower onset of action and is not appropriate in emergencies requiring immediate restoration of rhythm. It also carries a risk of arrhythmias, such as torsades de pointes.

Learning Objective:

AHA algorithm for tachycardia management:

choices.text: A- Z line B- A band C-I band D-H band
A-Z line B- I band C- A band D- H band
A-M line B-I band C-H band D-I band
A-M line B-I band C- A band D- H band

questions.text: Identify the marked ones in sarcomere?
questions.solution:
• A (Z line): Dark vertical line marking the boundary between sarcomeres and anchoring actin filaments.
  • B (I band): Light region containing only thin actin filaments; shortens during contraction.
  • C (A band): Dark region containing thick myosin filaments, with actin overlapping; remains unchanged in length.
  • D (H band): Lighter central part of A band with only myosin filaments; disappears during contraction.

questions.text: A 35-year-old right-handed female presents after a recent stroke with a lesion noted in the inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere on imaging.Which functional area is most likely to be impacted?
A patient goes through routine tests while applying for a job. His ECG showed a PR interval of 0.21 sect. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A PR interval of 0.21 seconds is diagnostic of first-degree heart block, as the normal range is 0.12-0.20 seconds, and a prolonged interval indicates delayed conduction through the AV node.

Normal rhythm (Option B): A PR interval of 0.21 seconds is prolonged beyond the normal range of 0.12-0.20 seconds, indicating that the rhythm is not normal, ruling out this option.

2nd-degree block (Option C): Mobitz Type I (Wenckebach) is characterized by progressive PR interval prolongation until a beat is dropped, which is not seen here. Mobitz Type II involves intermittent dropped beats but without PR interval progression, which is more severe than first-degree block but does not fit the described case.

Complete heart block (Option D), also known as third-degree AV block, involves complete dissociation between atrial and ventricular activity, where P waves and QRS complexes do not correlate, and the PR interval becomes irrelevant, which is not seen in this case.

Reference:

First-Degree Heart Block - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

1st degree heart block: Causes, symptoms, and treatment

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient came with complaints of palpitations, sweating, and restlessness. He has a complaint of sweaty palms. Clinical findings are depicted in the image given below. What is the diagnostic finding seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical presentation suggests Graves' disease, a form of hyperthyroidism. The symptoms, including palpitations, sweating, restlessness, and sweaty palms, are common in hyperthyroid states. The diagnostic finding in Graves' disease is elevated thyroid receptor antibodies. These antibodies, specifically thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulins (TSI), stimulate the thyroid gland, leading to excess production of thyroid hormones, resulting in hyperthyroid symptoms.

Graves' Disease is an autoimmune disorder causing hyperthyroidism due to thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulins (TSI) that stimulate the thyroid gland, increasing hormone production (T3 and T4).

Clinical Features:

  • Hyperthyroid symptoms: Palpitations, sweating, restlessness, weight loss, heat intolerance, tachycardia, hyperactivity, irritability.
  • Graves' ophthalmopathy: Exophthalmos, lid retraction, lid lag, conjunctival injection, dry eyes, visual disturbances.

Diagnosis:

  • Elevated TSI and thyroid function tests showing elevated T3/T4 and suppressed TSH.
  • Radioactive iodine uptake: Increased in Graves' disease.

Management:

  1. Antithyroid drugs: Propylthiouracil (PTU) or methimazole to inhibit thyroid hormone production.
  2. Radioactive iodine (RAI): Ablates overactive thyroid tissue but does not treat ophthalmopathy.
  3. Surgical treatment: Thyroidectomy if needed for large goiters or refractory cases.
  4. Graves' ophthalmopathy: Managed with corticosteroids, radiotherapy, or orbital decompression surgery for severe cases.

Anti-thyroglobulin antibody (Option A) and Anti-thyroid peroxidase antibody (Option B): These antibodies are elevated in conditions such as autoimmune hypothyroidism (e.g., Hashimoto's thyroiditis).

Elevated ultrasensitive thyrotropin (TSH) levels (Option D): TSH is typically low in hyperthyroid states like Graves' disease due to feedback inhibition, not elevated.

Reference:

Pubmed

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK582134/table/article-142674.table0/

https://eyewiki.org/Thyroid_Eye_Disease#:~:text=Eyelid%20retraction%20(Dalrymple's%20sign)%20is,bilateral%20axial%20proptosis%20(exophthalmos)

questions.text: ABG findings of a person presenting with abdominal pain and vomiting are as follows: pH: 7.31, HCO3-: 20 mEq/L, Na+: 135 mEq/L, K+: 5 mEq/L, Cl-: 92 mEq/L. Blood glucose: 450 mg/dL. What is the interpretation?
questions.solution:
The ABG findings and clinical presentation strongly indicate high anion gap metabolic acidosis.

Acidemia Confirmation:

pH = 7.31 (acidic)

HCO3- = 20 mEq/L (low)

confirming metabolic acidosis.

Calculate the Anion Gap (AG):

Anion Gap (AG) = [(Na⁺)-(Cl⁻ + HCO₃⁻)]

AG = 135-(92 + 20)= 135 - 112 = 23 mEq/L.

Normal AG: 8-12 mEq/L. AG > 12 indicates high anion gap metabolic acidosis.

Anion Gap Formula:

Anion Gap = [(Na⁺) - (Cl⁻ + HCO₃⁻)]

  • Na⁺ = Sodium concentration (mEq/L)
  • Cl⁻ = Chloride concentration (mEq/L)
  • HCO₃⁻ = Bicarbonate concentration (mEq/L)

Normal AG: 8-12 mEq/L. AG > 12 indicates high anion gap metabolic acidosis.

  • A high anion gap may indicate metabolic acidosis due to conditions like diabetic ketoacidosis, lactic acidosis, or renal failure.
  • A low anion gap can be seen in hypoalbuminemia or the presence of abnormal proteins.

Winter's formula

It is used to estimate the expected compensatory bicarbonate (HCO₃⁻) level in metabolic acidosis with a high anion gap (HAGMA).

(Expected bicarbonate (HCO₃⁻) = 24 + (1.5 × anion gap) - 8]

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK536919/

https://www.thoracic.org/professionals/clinical-resources/critical-care/clinical-education/abgs.php

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presents with facial puffiness, frothy urine, and elevated blood pressure. He has a past medical history of hepatitis B infection. Urinalysis reveals microscopic hematuria. A renal biopsy is performed, and the histological image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of nephrotic syndrome, including frothy urine (proteinuria), edema, and hypertension, combined with hepatitis B infection and the classic “spike and dome” appearance on renal biopsy, point toward membranous nephropathy, a common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults.

Membranous Nephropathy:

  • Most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in the elderly.
  • It is an immune complex-mediated glomerulopathy.
  • Associated Conditions:
    • Malignancies: Especially of the colon, lung, and melanoma.
    • Infections: Hepatitis B & C, syphilis, malaria, schistosomiasis.
    • Drugs: Gold, penicillamine.
    • Autoimmune diseases: Most notably systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).
  • Pathogenesis:
    • Primary Form:
      • Caused by autoantibodies against M-type phospholipase A2 receptor (PLA2R) on podocytes.
      • Triggers complement activation, especially through the membrane attack complex (C5b-9).
      • Results in subepithelial immune complex deposition resembling Heymann nephritis.
    • Other Antigens:
      • THSD7A and neutral endopeptidase (CD10) are alternative targets in some patients.
  • Diagnostic Marker:
    • Detection of anti-PLA2R antibodies is helpful for diagnosis and monitoring.

Explanation of other options:

Minimal change disease (Option A): Usually presents in children, not adults, and shows normal glomeruli on light microscopy with effacement of foot processes on electron microscopy, not a spike and dome pattern.

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) (Option C): Characterised by segmental sclerosis of some glomeruli, typically associated with obesity, HIV, or heroin use, not a spike and dome pattern and usually not linked with hepatitis B.

Post-streptococcal Glomerulonephritis (PSGN) (Option D): Presents with nephritic features (gross hematuria, hypertension) rather than nephrotic syndrome; biopsy shows subepithelial humps (not spikes and domes) in electron microscopy and is commonly preceded by a streptococcal infection, not hepatitis B.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents with fatigue and bleeding gums. Laboratory results show anemia, platelet count of 25,000/mm3, and prolonged PT and APTT. The peripheral blood smear shows the following image. Based on the smear findings, which of the following fusion genes is most likely involved?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of anemia, thrombocytopenia, and coagulopathy, along with the peripheral smear showing faggot cells with bundles of Auer rods, point towards a diagnosis of Acute promyelocytic leukemia (AML M3). The fusion gene most likely involved is PML-RARA.

Explanation of other options:

RUNX1-RUNX1T1 (Option B) (t[8;21]): This translocation is seen in AML with maturation (M2 subtype), typically presenting with large blasts and azurophilic granules, but faggot cells and severe coagulopathy like DIC are not common features.

INV(16) (Option C): Found in AML with abnormal eosinophils, it presents with eosinophil-rich marrow and lacks the characteristic promyelocyte accumulation or multiple Auer rods seen in APL.

IGH-NSD2 (Option D) (t[4;14]): Associated with multiple myeloma, not leukemia. It presents with bone pain, lytic lesions, hypercalcemia, and renal dysfunction, and does not feature Auer rods or coagulopathy.

questions.text: A patient undergoes lateral skull base surgery and subsequently develops aspiration without any change in voice. Which of the following nerve injuries is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
• The clinical picture of aspiration without hoarseness suggests an injury to the internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve, which supplies sensation to the supraglottic larynx.
  • This loss of sensation compromises airway protection during swallowing, leading to silent aspiration.
  • Since the recurrent laryngeal nerve and the cricothyroid (motor via external SLN) are intact, phonation remains unaffected.

Reference:https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC8305207/

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with parent-reported reduced hearing for 2-3 months, without fever or ear discharge. Otoscopy reveals a retracted, opaque tympanic membrane with visible fluid behind it. Based on the clinical presentation and otoscopic findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical history of progressive hearing loss, along with the otoscopic finding of a retracted and opaque tympanic membrane with visible fluid behind it, strongly points towards a diagnosis of Serous otitis media (also known as Otitis media with effusion).

Serous Otitis Media (SOM):

  • Etiology: Caused by Eustachian tube dysfunction due to adenoid hypertrophy, upper respiratory infections, or allergies.
  • Symptoms:
    • Gradual-onset conductive hearing loss (mild to moderate; often unnoticed by young children, parents may report it)
    • Speech delay in children (if longstanding)
    • Feeling of ear fullness
    • Occasionally mild discomfort; usually no fever or significant pain
  • Clinical Signs on Otoscopy:
    • Dull, opaque tympanic membrane may appear yellowish or bluish
    • Fluid or air bubbles are visible behind the eardrum
    • Retracted tympanic membrane, often with a shortened or horizontal malleus handle
    • Reduced mobility of the tympanic membrane on pneumatic otoscopy
  • Diagnostic Tests:

Explanation of other options:

Myringitis bullosa (Option A): This condition presents with painful, fluid-filled blisters on the tympanic membrane, often with significant redness, which is not observed here.

Acute otitis media (Option C): It typically shows a bulging, congested tympanic membrane with fever and/or ear pain, whereas here the membrane is retracted.

Pneumotympanum (Option D) involves air in the middle ear, often after barotrauma, with a hypermobile tympanic membrane, not described here.

questions.text: What is the function of the superior oblique muscle?
questions.solution: The superior oblique muscle, innervated by the trochlear nerve (CN IV), is responsible for intorsion, depression, and abduction of the eye. Dysfunction of this muscle causes vertical diplopia, particularly noticeable when looking down, such as when walking downstairs.

questions.text: Identify the defect shown in the image given below.
questions.solution:
Homonymous hemianopia refers to loss of vision in the same visual field (right or left) of both eyes.

  • It occurs due to lesions in the optic tract, lateral geniculate body, optic radiations, or occipital cortex.
  • Common causes include stroke, tumors, and traumatic brain injury affecting the contralateral side of the brain.
  • The visual field defect shown is Right Homonymous Hemianopia, which occurs due to a defect in the Left Occipital lobe.
  • Visual Pathway: Temporal fibers carry impulses from the Nasal field, and Nasal fibres carry the Temporal field.

Binasal hemianopia (Option A): Binasal hemianopia involves loss of vision in the nasal fields of both eyes.It is usually caused by bilateral lateral compression of the optic chiasm, such as in bilateral carotid artery aneurysms.

Bitemporal hemianopia (Option B): Bitemporal hemianopia presents with loss of vision in the temporal fields of both eyes. It occurs due to optic chiasm compression, commonly caused by pituitary adenomas, craniopharyngiomas, or suprasellar masses.

Altitudinal defect (Option D): Altitudinal defects affect either the upper or lower half of the visual field in one or both eyes. They are typically seen in ischemic optic neuropathy (AION, NAION) and retinal vascular occlusions.

Learning Objective:

choices.text: Between 20-24 weeks, one doctor's opinion is required
Between 20-24 weeks, MTP is only done if it is life-saving for the mother
MTP can be done up to 24 weeks in this case
MTP can be done after 24 weeks.

questions.text: A female presents at 22 weeks of pregnancy due to rape. Which statement is correct regarding medical termination of pregnancy (MTP)?
questions.solution:
According to the amended MTP Act, 2021, MTP is permitted up to 24 weeks in cases of rape, with the opinion of two doctors.

Timing for MTP:

  • Up to 20 weeks: One doctor's opinion is required.
  • Beyond 20 weeks and less than 24 weeks: Only allowed on therapeutic grounds to save the woman’s life and pregnancy caused due to rape (Two doctor's decision). (Option C)
  • Emergency cases: Any registered doctor can terminate if necessary to save the woman's life.
  • Beyond 24 week: It is generally not permitted unless severe fetal anomalies are detected that are incompatible with life, or if there is a threat to the mother's life or health. This requires the approval of a medical board. (Option D ruled out)

Between 20-24 weeks, one doctor's opinion is required (Option A): Under the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (Amendment) Act, 2021, for pregnancies between 20-24 weeks, the opinion of two doctors is required, not just one. This applies to specific categories, including survivors of sexual assault.

Between 20-24 weeks, MTP is only done if it is life-saving for the mother (Option B): While protecting the life of the mother is one consideration, MTP can also be performed during this period for other reasons, including if the pregnancy is a result of rape, or if there are significant fetal anomalies, without the need for the condition to be life-threatening to the mother.

References:

Legal Abortion Limit Raised up to 24 Weeks of Gestation for Substantial Foetal Anomalies or for Rape Victims: a Welcome Step for Women and Health Providers in India - PMC

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with a progressively spreading rash over the body. The rash became less red and itchy after using topical steroids. Examination shows the lesions seen in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical history of inappropriate steroid use leading to altered appearance of a typical fungal infection, along with the characteristic plaques with scaly, irregular borders and central clearing, strongly suggests Tinea incognito.

Tinea Incognito:

  • Superficial dermatophyte skin infection altered by improper use of topical or systemic steroids
  • Lesions tend to enlarge progressively, often with central clearing
  • Borders may remain scaly, but their sharp definition may be reduced
  • Redness and itching are often diminished due to the anti-inflammatory effect of steroids
  • The typical appearance of fungal infection is masked, leading to diagnostic confusion
  • Inflammatory signs such as scaling, redness, and itching are often mild or absent

Explanation of other options:

Tinea corporis (Option B): This presents as classic ringworm, characterized by well-defined, red, scaly, annular plaques. However, in this case, the rash is modified due to steroid use, making typical features less obvious.

Tinea cruris (Option C): Fungal infection limited to the groin, inner thighs, or buttocks. The lesions here are more widespread, involving other body areas.

Tinea pedis (Option D): Fungal infection confined to the feet, often between toes or on soles. The patient's rash affects areas beyond the feet.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents with progressive difficulty climbing stairs and combing her hair. On examination, she has a violaceous rash over the eyelids and scaly erythematous papules over the knuckles. What is the most distinctive and characteristic finding in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of difficulty in climbing stairs and combing her hair, along with a violaceous eyelid rash and scaly papules over the knuckles, point towards a diagnosis of juvenile dermatomyositis. The most distinctive and characteristic finding in this condition is Gottron's papules.


Juvenile Dermatomyositis (JDM):

  • Rare autoimmune inflammatory muscle disease seen in children
  • Characterised by muscle weakness and distinctive skin lesions
  • Clinical Features:
    • Muscle Involvement:
      • Symmetrical weakness of proximal muscles (shoulders, hips)
      • Difficulty with activities like climbing stairs or getting up from a seated position
      • Gower's sign may be positive in severe cases
    • Skin Manifestations:
      • Gottron's papules: Violaceous, scaly papules over knuckles, elbows, knees (highly characteristic)
      • Heliotrope rash: Purple discoloration around the eyelids
      • Nailfold capillary changes: Dilated loops, capillary dropouts
      • Photosensitivity and facial redness (erythema)
    • Systemic Features:
      • Difficulty swallowing (dysphagia)
      • Lung involvement (interstitial lung disease)
      • Calcinosis cutis (calcium deposits in soft tissues, seen in chronic disease)
  • Diagnosis:
    • Elevated muscle enzymes (Creatine kinase, aldolase)
    • MRI: Detects muscle inflammation (oedema)
    • EMG: Shows myopathic patterns
    • Muscle biopsy: Perifascicular muscle fibre atrophy, inflammatory cell infiltrates
    • Autoantibodies: ANA, Anti-Mi-2, Anti-MDA5 (helpful for subtyping)
  • Management:
    • First-line treatment: Oral corticosteroids (e.g., prednisolone) + immunosuppressants (e.g., methotrexate, azathioprine)
    • Refractory cases: IV immunoglobulin (IVIG) or rituximab
    • Supportive care: Physiotherapy to preserve muscle strength and prevent contractures

Explanation of other options:

Photosensitive skin rash (Option A): Common in many autoimmune diseases like lupus and dermatomyositis, but it is not specific or distinctive enough to confidently identify the condition.

Nail bed capillary changes (Option B): These may be seen in this condition but are subtle and not as specific or characteristic as Gottron’s papules.

Malar rash (Option D): Classically associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), not this condition, and typically spares the nasolabial folds, unlike the facial rash in this case.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with the skin lesions shown in the image. He also complains of abnormal sensations in the affected area, describing it as feeling like something crawling on the skin. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows clusters of fluid-filled vesicles arranged along a single dermatome, a classic feature of Herpes zoster (shingles). The patient's complaint of abnormal skin sensations, such as crawling or tingling, often occurs before the rash develops and is due to nerve involvement from reactivation of the Varicella-zoster virus (VZV).

Herpes Zoster (Shingles):

  • Cause: Reactivation of dormant Varicella-zoster virus (VZV), which remains latent in sensory nerve ganglia after primary infection (chickenpox)
  • Predisposing Factors:
    • Older age (commonly over 50 years)
    • Weakened immunity (HIV, cancer, immunosuppressive drugs)
    • Chronic illnesses like diabetes
    • Psychological or physical stress
  • Clinical Features:
    • Skin Lesions:
      • Painful, grouped fluid-filled vesicles on a red (erythematous) base
      • Lesions follow the path of a single nerve (dermatomal distribution)
      • Commonly affects the thoracic, lumbar, or branches of the trigeminal nerve
      • Typically appears on one side of the body (unilateral)
    • Prodromal Symptoms:
      • Tingling, burning, or abnormal skin sensations (paresthesia)
      • Described as a "spider crawling sensation" by patients
      • May be accompanied by fever or general malaise
  • Complications:
    • Postherpetic neuralgia (PHN): Persistent nerve pain in the affected area
    • Secondary bacterial infection of the skin
    • Eye involvement (ophthalmic zoster) if the first branch of the trigeminal nerve is affected
  • Diagnosis:
    • Usually based on clinical appearance
    • Tzanck smear: Shows multinucleated giant cells
    • PCR test for virus detection if the diagnosis is unclear
  • Treatment:
    • Start antiviral medications (acyclovir, valacyclovir, famciclovir) within 72 hours to reduce severity and complications
    • Pain relief with analgesics
    • Corticosteroids may be considered in severe pain or inflammation
  • Prevention: Vaccination is recommended for older adults and high-risk groups to lower the risk of shingles and its complications

Explanation of other options:

Irritant contact dermatitis (Option B): Caused by direct chemical or physical damage to the skin, presenting with redness, scaling, or burning but does not follow a dermatomal pattern and lacks prodromal nerve-related symptoms like paresthesia.

Allergic contact dermatitis (Option C): A delayed hypersensitivity reaction leading to itchy, red, and sometimes vesicular lesions at the site of allergen exposure, but there is no dermatomal distribution or associated nerve pain.

Herpes simplex infection (Option D): Typically causes grouped vesicles on an erythematous base, most often around the lips (HSV-1) or genitals (HSV-2), and unlike zoster, does not follow a dermatomal distribution and usually lacks a clear prodromal nerve-related sensation like crawling.

choices.text: Produces non-lactose fermenting colonies on MacConkey agar.
Exhibits satellitism around Staphylococcus aureus colonies.
It exhibits alpha hemolysis on sheep blood agar.

questions.text: A child presents with high-grade fever, multiple episodes of seizures, headache, and neck stiffness. CSF examination shows low glucose, elevated protein, and a high neutrophil count. CSF culture reveals small, pleomorphic, gram-negative bacilli. Which of the following statements regarding the most likely causative organism is correct?
questions.solution:
• The clinical features of fever, seizures, neck stiffness, and CSF findings with pleomorphic gram-negative bacilli point towards a diagnosis of Haemophilus influenzae meningitis.
  • In regions with high Hib vaccination coverage, H. influenzae meningitis is less common, but it remains a key cause in unvaccinated or under-vaccinated children, particularly for type b strains.
  • H. influenzae requires two factors for growth: Factor X (hemin) and Factor V (NAD)
  • On blood agar, when grown near Staphylococcus aureus, the release of NAD by Staphylococcus enhances the growth of H. influenzae, a phenomenon known as satellitism.

Haemophilus influenzae:

  • Clinical Features:
    • Meningitis: Fever, irritability, stiff neck
    • Other Severe Infections: Acute epiglottitis, pneumonia, septic arthritis
    • Mucosal Infections (Usually nontypeable strains): Middle ear infection (otitis media), sinusitis
  • Diagnostic Approach:
    • Cerebrospinal Fluid (CSF) Findings in Meningitis:
      • Raised protein levels
      • Decreased glucose
      • Increased white blood cells (pleocytosis)
    • Microbiological Identification:
      • Gram Stain: Shows small, gram-negative coccobacilli
      • Culture: Grows on chocolate agar (provides essential growth factors)
      • Antigen Detection: Latex agglutination test for rapid diagnosis
      • Molecular Testing: PCR for confirmation and serotype identification
  • Management:
    • First-line Treatment:
      • Third-generation cephalosporins:
        • Ceftriaxone
        • Cefotaxime
    • Alternative Therapy:
      • Chloramphenicol (for those allergic to cephalosporins)
    • Treatment Duration:
      • Typically 10 days for cases of meningitis

Explanation of other options:

It is bacitracin sensitive (Option A): Bacitracin sensitivity is a characteristic of Haemophilus ducreyi, the causative agent of chancroid, whereas H. influenzae is typically resistant to bacitracin.

Produces non-lactose fermenting colonies on MacConkey agar (Option B): H. influenzae does not grow on MacConkey agar at all, as it requires special growth factors (hemin and NAD) provided by chocolate agar, which are absent in MacConkey medium.

It exhibits alpha hemolysis on sheep blood agar (Option D): Alpha hemolysis is seen with organisms like Streptococcus pneumoniae, whereas H. influenzae does not produce hemolysis on blood agar unless satellitism occurs near Staphylococcus aureus.

choices.text: 4 tablets of artesunate 50 mg + 6 tablets of primaquine 2.5 mg
4 tablets of artesunate 50 mg + sulphadoxine 1500 mg + 6 tablets of primaquine 2.5 mg
4 tablets of artesunate 50 mg + sulphadoxine 1500 mg + 6 tablets of primaquine 7.5 mg
4 tablets of artesunate 50 mg + 6 tablets of primaquine 7.5 mg

questions.text: A man from North India presents with a mixed infection of Plasmodium vivax and Plasmodium falciparum. What is the dosage of treatment given on the second day?
questions.solution:
For the treatment of mixed malaria infection with Plasmodium vivax and Plasmodium falciparum, the treatment regimen typically includes artesunate for blood stages & P. falciparum and primaquine for liver stages & P. vivax.

Treatment of Malaria:

choices.text: Release of noradrenaline at synaptic cleft
Selectively and irreversibly inhibit nicotinic receptors

questions.text: An elderly woman received a Botox injection to treat wrinkles. Which of the following is the mechanism of action of botulinum toxin?
questions.solution:
• Botulinum toxin, produced by Clostridium botulinum, works by selectively and irreversibly blocking the release of acetylcholine (ACh) from presynaptic neurons at the neuromuscular junction, which leads to muscle relaxation.
  • Therapeutically, type A botulinum toxin (e.g., Onabotulinum Toxin A) is preferred for its effectiveness. Side effects may include dry mouth, muscle weakness, difficulty swallowing, and drooping eyelids.
  • This effect is temporary, and that is why it is used for cosmetic purposes (e.g., reducing wrinkles) and medical conditions such as spasticity, dystonia, and hyperhydrosis.

Release of noradrenaline at synaptic cleft (Option B): This is not the mechanism of action of botulinum toxin. Noradrenaline is a neurotransmitter in the sympathetic nervous system, and botulinum toxin primarily affects acetylcholine release in the somatic motor system.

Selectively and irreversibly inhibit nicotinic receptors (Option C): Botulinum toxin does bind to nicotinic receptors, and its effects are long-term but not irreversible.

Stimulates muscarinic and nicotinic receptors (Option D): This is the opposite of the action of botulinum toxin. It does not stimulate muscarinic or nicotinic receptors but instead prevents the release of acetylcholine, which would normally activate these receptors.

Learning Objective:

  • Acetylcholine is a neurotransmitter essential for transmitting nerve impulses at the neuromuscular junction. It binds to nicotinic receptors on the muscle cell membrane, triggering muscle contraction.
  • Botulinum toxin, produced by Clostridium botulinum, inhibits acetylcholine release by selectively targeting cholinergic neurons.
    • It binds to presynaptic membranes, enters the neuron, and cleaves proteins critical for docking and fusing acetylcholine-containing vesicles with the presynaptic membrane.
    • This prevents acetylcholine release, resulting in muscle paralysis.
  • Types: Among the botulinum toxin types (A → H), Type A (BTX-A) is the most effective and widely used therapeutically in humans, followed by Type B.
  • Uses of Botulinum toxin:
    • Relieve Muscle spasticity (rigidity)
    • Blepharospasm: Eyelids not opening
    • Achalasia: Dysphagia due to LES spasm
    • Torticollis / Wry neck: Sternocleidomastoid muscle rigidity
    • Squint: Contraction of one eye; both eyes are not in coordination, causing double vision
    • Relieve migraine pain
    • For the treatment of hyperhidrosis
    • For cosmetic procedures: Reduces wrinkles

choices.text: Miscarriage with the consent of the mother
Causing miscarriage without the consent of the mother
Death of the mother by act done with intent to cause miscarriage
Causing the death of the quick unborn child by an act amounting to culpable homicide

questions.text: Section 314 IPC deals with
questions.solution:
Section 314 IPC

  • Death caused by an act done with intent to cause miscarriage, if act done without woman's consent.
  • Now it corresponds to BNS 90.

Reference: https://www.indiacode.nic.in/repealedfileopen?rfilename=A1860-45.pdf (page 8)

CORRESPONDENCE TABLE and COMPARISON SUMMARY OF THE BHARTATIYA NYAYA SANHITA, 2023 (BNS) to THE INDIAN PENAL CODE, 1860 (IPC)

questions.text: A 25-year-old professional athlete with a BMI of 17.5 kg/m2 presents with complaints of secondary amenorrhea and primary infertility. Her laboratory investigations reveal FSH of 2 mIU/mL, LH of 0.3 mIU/mL, TSH of 1.2 mIU/mL, and prolactin of 20 ng/mL. What is the most likely underlying cause of her condition?
questions.solution:
The patient has low FSH and LH levels with a normal TSH and prolactin, along with a history of low BMI and high physical activity, which are classic features of functional hypothalamic amenorrhea, a form of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.

Hypogonadotropic Hypogonadism (HH):

  • Caused by dysfunction at the level of the hypothalamus or pituitary, leading to insufficient secretion of gonadotropins (LH, FSH).
  • Classification:
    • Congenital HH:
      • Anosmic HH (e.g., Kallmann syndrome):
        • Associated with absent or reduced sense of smell.
        • MRI may reveal abnormal or absent olfactory bulbs.
      • Normosmic Isolated HH:
        • Sense of smell remains normal.
    • Acquired HH: Can occur due to tumors, trauma, weight loss, excessive exercise, stress, systemic illness, or medications.
  • Clinical Characteristics:
    • Reduced androgen levels leading to:
      • Decreased libido
      • Erectile dysfunction (in males)
      • Muscle weakness
      • Increased body fat
    • Delayed or absent sexual maturation
    • Menstrual irregularities or amenorrhea in females
    • Infertility
    • Low bone density
    • Mood disturbances such as low mood and fatigue
  • Diagnosis:
    • Low levels of LH, FSH and Estradiol or testosterone
    • GnRH stimulation test may help confirm the diagnosis
    • MRI of the brain may be required, especially in anosmic cases, to assess olfactory structures
  • Management:
    • Hormonal Replacement Therapy: Induces sexual development and maintains secondary sexual characteristics
    • Treatment of Underlying Cause: For acquired cases, addressing the primary issue (e.g., nutritional, stress, tumors)
    • Fertility Treatment: Ovulation induction with GnRH or gonadotropins for women desiring pregnancy

Explanation of other options:

Primary ovarian failure (Option A): This condition causes elevated FSH and LH due to loss of ovarian function; in this case, both gonadotropins are low, ruling it out.

Hypergonadotropic Hypogonadism (Option C): Marked by high FSH and LH levels because of ovarian failure, which is inconsistent with the patient’s low FSH and LH values.

Normogonadotropic Normogonadism (Option D): Gonadotropin levels are within the normal range in this condition, often seen with PCOS or structural causes, but the suppressed FSH and LH levels in this patient exclude this possibility.

Reference:

  1. https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3583156/
  2. https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/medicine-and-dentistry/hypogonadotropic-hypogonadism
  3. https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0140673610603558

questions.text:
A 36-week pregnant woman presents with elevated blood pressure and urine showing 3+ proteinuria. Which combination of the following symptoms would raise concern for developing eclampsia?
1. Headache
2. Blurred vision
3. Persistent pedal oedema
4. Epigastric pain
questions.solution:
In women with pre-eclampsia, symptoms such as headache, visual disturbances (like blurred vision), and epigastric or right upper quadrant pain are considered warning signs that the condition may progress to eclampsia.

Warning Signs Suggesting Imminent Eclampsia:

  • Blood pressure ≥160/110 mmHg on two readings at rest
  • Significant proteinuria (≥3+ on dipstick or high levels on 24-hour collection)
  • Oliguria or anuria
  • Epigastric or right upper quadrant pain (Statement 4)
  • Headache (Statement 1)
  • Visual disturbances (e.g., blurred vision, diplopia, scotomata, amaurosis fugax) (Statement 2)
  • Pulmonary edema or cyanosis
  • Organ dysfunction (e.g., elevated liver enzymes, abnormal kidney function)

Management:

  • Seizure prevention: Magnesium sulfate (MgSO₄)
  • Blood pressure control: Antihypertensive medications
  • Fetal lung maturity: Corticosteroids if <34 weeks gestation
  • Definitive treatment: Delivery of the baby

Explanation of other options:

Persistent pedal edema (Statement 3) is common in pregnancy and pre-eclampsia but not a specific indicator of eclampsia risk.

Reference:

  1. https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/22495060/
  2. https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/7658039/

choices.text: Years lost due to premature death
Years lost to poor quality of life

questions.text: The years of potential life lost could be attributed to:
questions.solution:
• Years of potential life lost due to premature death.
  • Example: If a 30-year-old dies, potentially losing 45 years of life (assuming a life expectancy of 75).
  • YPLL is a mortality indicator, less sensitive in developed nations with better disease control.


Years lost to morbidity (Option A): YPLL refers to premature death, not morbidity.

questions.text: Calculate the infant mortality rate of a town with a population of 20,000, based on the following data: In a year, there were a total of 456 births, out of which 56 were stillborn. The total number of deaths was 247, with 56 deaths occurring within 28 days of life, and an additional 34 deaths occurring after 28 days but before completing the first birthday. Calculate the infant mortality rate of the area.
questions.solution:
Step-by-step Calculation:

  1. Identify the total live births:
    • Total births = 456
    • Stillbirths = 56
    • Live births = Total births - Stillbirths = 456 - 56 = 400
  2. Determine the total number of infant deaths (under 1 year):
    • Neonatal deaths (within 28 days) = 56
    • Post-neonatal deaths (28 days to 1 year) = 34
    • Total infant deaths = Neonatal deaths + Post-neonatal deaths = 56 + 34 = 90
  3. Calculate the infant mortality rate:
    • Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) = (Number of infant deaths under 1 year / Total live births) × 1000
    • For this question:
      • Number of infant deaths under 1 year = 90
      • Total live births = 400
    • So, IMR = (90 / 400) × 1000 = 225

Infant mortality rate (IMR): is expressed as the number of deaths of infants (aged 0-1 year) per 1000 live births in a given year.

Infant mortality rate (IMR) = (No. of deaths of children (infant) 0-1 year of life / live births) x 1000)

Causes:

  • The most common cause is low birth weight/prematurity according to the latest update
  • Other causes include asphyxia, ARIs, diarrhea, congenital anomalies, cord infection, birth trauma, and others.
  • Most infant deaths occur within the first month of life, with a significant proportion (54.6%) occurring during the first week.
  • The risk of death is highest within the first 24-48 hours after birth.
  • IMR reflects the effectiveness of maternal and child health (MCH) services and overall healthcare infrastructure in preventing infant deaths.

Reference: Child Health

questions.text: What is the most appropriate next step in the management of a female patient who has abdominal pain, multiple gallstones with no thickening of the gallbladder wall as seen on ultrasound, a common bile duct diameter of 12mm, serum bilirubin level of 0.8, alkaline phosphatase level of 380, and a 5-fold increase in GGT?
questions.solution:
• The patient has multiple gallstones, and the CBD diameter is increased at 12mm, which suggests the possibility of choledocholithiasis (stones in the common bile duct).
  • The elevated alkaline phosphatase and significantly raised GGT levels also indicate some degree of biliary obstruction.
  • MRCP can accurately assess the CBD and help identify the presence, location, and size of any stones within the duct.
  • It can also evaluate the pancreatic duct for any associated pathology. By obtaining this information, MRCP can guide further management decisions and determine the most appropriate intervention, whether it's endoscopic or surgical.

ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography) (Option B) ERCP can be therapeutic and used for stone removal, it is typically reserved for cases where there is a clear indication for intervention, such as symptomatic choledocholithiasis or evidence of biliary obstruction with significant symptoms or abnormal liver function tests.

Endoscopic ultrasound (Option C) EUS can be useful for evaluating certain conditions, such as pancreatic tumours or staging of gastrointestinal malignancies, it is not the primary modality for assessing gallstones or the biliary system.

Laparoscopic cholecystectomy (Option D)in this case, the focus is primarily on the evaluation of the biliary system. Therefore, performing a cholecystectomy without further assessment and identification of possible choledocholithiasis would be premature.

choices.text: Direct hernia and Lichtenstein mesh repair
Indirect hernia and Lichtenstein mesh repair

questions.text: A patient presents with a hernia medial to the inferior epigastric artery. What is the most likely diagnosis and appropriate management for the same?
questions.solution:
• The medial bulge near the inferior epigastric vessels suggests a direct Inguinal Hernia, which protrudes through a weakness in Hesselbach's triangle and is treated with Lichtenstein mesh repair.
  • It is a condition where the viscus protrudes through a weak spot in the abdominal wall (Direct inguinal hernia) or inguinal canal in the groin area (Indirect inguinal hernia). (Option C, and D ruled out)

Management of Inguinal Hernia:

Surgical Approaches:

  • Herniotomy:
    • It involves excising and closing the hernia sac
    • Primarily used in children with lateral hernias and congenital hydrocele.
    • In adults, herniotomy alone is insufficient due to high recurrence rates.
  • Hernioplasty: Includes herniotomy plus inguinal floor reconstruction with mesh.
  • Herniorrhaphy:
    • Includes herniotomy plus reconstruction of the inguinal floor with sutures

Anterior Tension-Free Repair:

  • Lichtenstein Repair (preferred): Utilizes a mesh to reinforce the inguinal floor, which is considered the gold standard due to lower recurrence rates and faster recovery. (Option A ruled out)

Open Preperitoneal Repair:

  • Stoppa Repair:
    • Uses a mesh to reinforce the area behind the peritoneum
    • Done in Recurrent inguinal hernia

Laparoscopic Hernia Repair:

  • Totally Extraperitoneal (TEP) Repair
  • Transabdominal Preperitoneal (TAPP) Repair

Learning Objectives:

choices.text: Most commonly seen < 5 years of age
Majority of patients recover due to chemotherapy and radiotherapy
Lung involvement is uncommon and occurs late

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding wilm's tumour is not true
questions.solution:
• Lung metastasis is actually common in Wilms tumours and can occur early in the disease, especially if the tumour is not detected and treated promptly.
  • Wilms' Tumor (Nephroblastoma) is a common malignant renal tumour in children (commonly < 5 years of age), usually unilateral but can be bilateral. It is caused by mutations in the WT1 and WT2 genes on chromosome 11. (Option B ruled out)

questions.text: A teacher demonstrates the proper handwashing technique to her students, who then practice it both at school and at home. What type of learning does this scenario represent?
questions.solution:
The steps of handwashing demonstrated by the teacher and performed by the students are an example of Psychomotor learning.


Reference:

Domains of cognition and their assessment - PMC

Development of a short and universal learning self-efficacy scale for clinical skills - PMC

questions.text:
A patient with a history of chronic alcohol use (24 units per day for the past 10 years) presents with seizures, altered mental status, auditory hallucinations, and secondary delusions. His last alcohol consumption was 2 days ago. What is the appropriate management for this patient?
1. Diazepam
2. Thiamine
3. Naltrexone
4. Flupenthixol depot injection
questions.solution:
• The symptoms suggest that the patient is suffering from delirium tremens, and the appropriate treatment includes benzodiazepines (diazepam) for withdrawal symptoms and thiamine to prevent neurological complications like Wernicke Encephalopathy or Korsakoff psychosis.
  • Delirium tremens is a severe withdrawal syndrome that occurs after sudden cessation of chronic alcohol consumption. It is characterized by confusion, agitation, hallucinations, autonomic hyperactivity and seizures.
  • Seizures can occur suddenly; about 1% may experience a single grand mal convulsion, typically on the second day of withdrawal.
  • Treatment of choice: Benzodiazepines.
  • Anticonvulsants are not more beneficial.

(Option C): Naltrexone is an opioid antagonist used to treat alcohol dependence by reducing cravings, but it is not indicated in the acute withdrawal phase. It is more useful for maintaining abstinence once the patient has been stabilized and no longer requires acute management.

(Options A & B): Flupenthixol is an antipsychotic used to treat schizophrenia or other psychotic disorders, not alcohol withdrawal. Although the patient has auditory hallucinations and delusions, these are likely related to alcohol withdrawal, which should be treated with benzodiazepines.
